sentence: Looking at the universe of stocks we cover at Dividend Channel , in trading on Wednesday, shares of Procter & Gamble Co. (Symbol: PG) were yielding above the 3% mark based on its quarterly dividend (annualized to $2.7584), with the stock changing hands as low as $91.66 on the day.
Dividends are particularly important for investors to consider, because historically speaking dividends have provided a considerable share of the stock market's total return.
To illustrate, suppose for example you purchased shares of the S&P 500 ETF ( SPY ) back on 12/31/1999 - you would have paid $146.88 per share.
Fast forward to 12/31/2012 and each share was worth $142.41 on that date, a decrease of $4.67/share over all those years.
But now consider that you collected a whopping $25.98 per share in dividends over the same period, for a positive total return of 23.36%.

Even with dividends reinvested, that only amounts to an average annual total return of about 1.6%; so by comparison collecting a yield above 3% would appear considerably attractive if that yield is sustainable.
Procter & Gamble Co. (Symbol: PG) is an S&P 500 company, giving it special status as one of the large-cap companies making up the S&P 500 Index.
In general, dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company.

In the case of Procter & Gamble Co., looking at the history chart for PG below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue, and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 3% annual yield.
According to the ETF Finder at ETF Channel, PG makes up 12.67% of the Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR Fund ETF (Symbol: XLP) which is trading higher by about 0.1% on the day Wednesday.
PG has been growing its dividend for more than 20 years consecutively.
